answer_html: \(\lambda=1 \text{ or } 5\) Thus, the eigenvalues of \({\color{blue}\displaystyle A}\)are \({\color{blue}\displaystyle \lambda_{1} = 1, \,\lambda_{2} = 5}\).
answer_latex: $\lambda=1 \text{ or } 5$  Thus, the eigenvalues of ${\color{blue}\displaystyle A}$are ${\color{blue}\displaystyle \lambda_{1} = 1, \,\lambda_{2} = 5}$.
hints_html:
The eigenvalues \(\displaystyle \lambda_{i}\) of \(\displaystyle A\) satisfy the equation

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \det(A - \lambda_{i} I) = 0\end{aligned}\]

where \(\displaystyle I\) is the identity matrix with the same dimensions as \(\displaystyle A\).
hints_latex:
The eigenvalues $\displaystyle \lambda_{i}$ of $\displaystyle A$ satisfy
the equation

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle \det(A - \lambda_{i} I) = 0
\end{align*} where $\displaystyle I$ is
the identity matrix with the same dimensions as $\displaystyle A$.
hints_raw:
The eigenvalues <math>\displaystyle \lambda_{i}</math> of <math>\displaystyle A</math> satisfy the equation
:<math>
\displaystyle \det(A - \lambda_{i} I) = 0
</math>
where <math>\displaystyle I</math> is the identity matrix with the same dimensions as <math>\displaystyle A</math>.
question: 4 (a)
sols_html:
To determine the eigenvalues, \(\displaystyle \lambda_{1},\,\lambda_{2}\), of \(\displaystyle A\), we solve for the characteristic polynomial of \(\displaystyle A\) for \(\displaystyle \lambda\):

\[\begin{aligned} \det(A - \lambda I) &= 0 \\ \det\left(\left[\begin{array}{cc} 3 - \lambda & 2 \\ 2 & 3 - \lambda \end{array} \right]\right) &= 0 \\ (3 - \lambda)^{2} - 4 &= 0 \\ (3 - \lambda)^{2} &= 4 \\ 3 - \lambda &= \pm2 \\ \lambda &= -(-3 \pm 2) \\ \lambda &= 1 \text{ or } 5 \end{aligned}\]

Thus, the eigenvalues of \({\color{blue}\displaystyle A}\)are \({\color{blue}\displaystyle \lambda_{1} = 1, \,\lambda_{2} = 5}\).
sols_latex:
To determine the eigenvalues, $\displaystyle \lambda_{1},\,\lambda_{2}$,
of $\displaystyle A$, we solve for the characteristic polynomial of
$\displaystyle A$ for $\displaystyle \lambda$:

\begin{align*}
\det(A - \lambda I) &= 0 \\
\det\left(\left[\begin{array}{cc} 3 - \lambda & 2 \\ 2 & 3 - \lambda \end{array}  \right]\right) &= 0 \\
(3 - \lambda)^{2} - 4 &= 0 \\
(3 - \lambda)^{2}  &= 4 \\
3 - \lambda  &= \pm2 \\
\lambda &= -(-3 \pm 2) \\
\lambda &= 1 \text{ or } 5 
\end{align*} Thus, the eigenvalues of ${\color{blue}\displaystyle A}$are ${\color{blue}\displaystyle \lambda_{1} = 1, \,\lambda_{2} = 5}$.
sols_raw:
To determine the eigenvalues, <math>\displaystyle \lambda_{1},\,\lambda_{2}</math>, of <math>\displaystyle A</math>, we solve for the <b>characteristic polynomial</b> of <math>\displaystyle A</math> for <math>\displaystyle \lambda</math>:
:<math>
\begin{align}
\det(A - \lambda I) &= 0 \\
\det\left(\left[\begin{array}{cc} 3 - \lambda & 2 \\ 2 & 3 - \lambda \end{array}  \right]\right) &= 0 \\
(3 - \lambda)^{2} - 4 &= 0 \\
(3 - \lambda)^{2}  &= 4 \\
3 - \lambda  &= \pm2 \\
\lambda &= -(-3 \pm 2) \\
\lambda &= 1 \text{ or } 5 
\end{align}
</math>
<font style="color:blue;">Thus, the eigenvalues of <math>{\color{blue}\displaystyle A}</math> are <math>{\color{blue}\displaystyle \lambda_{1} = 1, \,\lambda_{2} = 5}</math>.</font>
statement_html:
Consider the matrix

\[\begin{aligned} A=\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 2\\ 2 & 3 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

Find the eigenvalues of A (there will be two distinct eigenvalues).
